primary health care (PHC). The Project consists of four components:

In  2006,  the  Government  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  cooperate

alleviate  poverty,  accelerate  economic  growth,  and  reduce  disparities  in  the  development 
process,  particularly  between  rural  and  urban  areas.  The  Project  is  in  line  with  the 
Government’s development strategy, and it is included in the ADB’s Mongolia Country Strategy 
Program and Update (2007–2009). The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

In  the  early  1990s,  Mongolia  inherited  a  Soviet-style  health  system  with  a  large,

characterized  by  poorly  developed  PHC,  financing  systems,  human  resources  (HR)  and 
planning, and regulatory processes. Together, these factors contributed to the health system’s 
requiring overall reform and realignment. 
 
4. 
ADB  has  cooperated  closely  with  the  Government  to  identify  and  implement  reform 
priorities, which are (i) to transform the hospital-dominated system towards PHC; (ii) develop the 
capacity  to  plan,  finance,  manage,  and  monitor  the  health  system;  and  (iii)  upgrade  health 
service infrastructure. In 1997, under HSDP, ADB provided initial support for critical changes in 
the  Mongolian  health  care  system.  Key  initiatives  supported  by  HSDP  include  developing  the 
family  group  practice  (FGP)  system  (teams  of  family  doctors  and  nurses  providing  treatment 
and  prevention  services  to  the  population)  as  a  means  of  transforming  the  health  system 
towards  PHC,

As a result of this cooperation, there has been significant progress in a number of areas. 
This is evidenced by improved health outcomes with continuing decreases in important sector 
indicators,  including  the  infant  mortality  and  maternal  mortality  rates.  However,  major  reform 
initiatives have yet to be fully implemented and to achieve sustainable impact. The FGP system, 
established  nationwide  in  2002,  is  the  cornerstone  of  the  reform  process  and  still  needs 
consolidation and further investment, the hospital sector is still excessive and attracts the bulk of 
health  expenditure,  health  financing  mechanisms  do  not  sufficiently  target  efficiency,  HR 
capacity and policies are still weak, and lack of governance and regulatory capacity has resulted 
in  unrestricted  private  sector  growth  and  ineffective  monitoring  systems.  An  overview  of  the 
Mongolian health sector and performance issues is in Appendix 2. An assessment of the FGP 
system in Mongolia is in Supplementary Appendix A.  
 
7. 
The Mongolian health care system is in a critical phase. In many areas, implementation 
of reforms has been incomplete, resulting in initially modest results and transformations. Without 
clear strategic and policy directions and further targeted support, many reform initiatives are in 
danger of drifting. The Government has endorsed a Health Sector Master Plan (HSMP) to bring 
together resources, policies, and strategies to guide the reform agenda, and there is recognition 
by international partners of the need to provide continued support to reforms.  
 
8. 
The Government approved the HSMP in April 2005. That plan was developed through a 
consultative process, and it serves as a comprehensive technical long-term planning document 
(for  2006–2015)  in  line  with  Mongolia’s  desire  to  achieve  the  Millennium  Development  Goals 
(MDGs).  Main  strategies  of  the  HSMP  include  (i)  further  increasing  coverage,  access  and 
utilization of health services, and especially for disadvantaged groups, through promoting quality 
PHC; (ii) strengthening health human resources skills and management; (iii) strengthening the 
financial  management  system  to  improve  resources  use;  (iv)  improving  the  health  insurance 
system; and (v) supporting a sector-wide health care approach to improve coordination of inputs 
and  resources  management.  Donor  support  for  the  Mongolian  health  sector  is  detailed  in 
Appendix 3. A timely opportunity now exists for the Project to consolidate reform initiatives and 
further develop and implement strategies to strengthen Mongolia’s health care system.

Variation  in  Health  Indicators.  In  important  indicator  areas,  including  infant  mortality, 
under  5-mortality,  and maternal  mortality,  Mongolia  is  making  good  progress  overall  (although 
the maternal mortality rate of 93 per 100,000 live births is still considered relatively high) and is 
likely to achieve the MDGs and targets for child health, maternal health, and universal access to 
reproductive  health.  Within  the  overall  indicators,  however,  there  are  significant  regional 
variations,  with  some  aimags  (provinces)  recording  rates  2–3  times  higher  than  the  national 
average for maternal mortality. Aimag averages for key indicators are consistently poorer than 
the  Ulaanbaatar  city  averages,  suggesting  significant  inequity  in  service  provision  between 
urban  and  rural  areas.  In  general,  the  rural  health  system  has  lower  quality  services,  less 
qualified staff, and lower levels of infrastructure and equipment.

35. Poverty is a major factor affecting poor health outcomes. Despite recent gains in Mongolia’s

12. 
Low Quality of Rural Health Services. The quality of rural health services provided by 
bag feldshers (community nurses) and in soum (administrative unit of the aimag) health centers 
(SHCs) is generally worse than are services provided in urban areas. This reflects isolation and 
remoteness,  scarce  HR  capacity  and  skills  in  the  countryside,  problems  in  attracting  and 
retaining staff, reduced training and continuing education opportunities, and lack of professional 
and  clinical  support.  Infrastructure,  equipment,  and  supplies  are  generally  of  a  much  lower 
standard  in  rural  areas.  The  Government  and  MOH  have  developed  rural  health  programs  to 
upgrade  SHCs,  establish  regional  diagnostic  and  treatment  centers  in  three  aimags  across 
Mongolia,  and  improve  communication  and  access  to  remote  consultations  and  specialist 
support.  The  Japan  Fund  for  Information  and  Communications  Technology  grant  project 3 
associated with SHDSP also focuses on improving technological capacity to link SHCs to aimag 
general  hospitals  (AGHs),  with  an  emphasis  on  maternal  and  child  health  outcomes. 
Nevertheless, rural health improvement still lags significantly behind urban health development, 
and Ulaanbaatar still attracts most of development assistance. 
 
Poor  Hospital  Service  Quality.  Services provided in aimag, duureg (Ulaanbaatar City 
13. 
district), and tertiary hospitals are perceived as low quality by much of the population, evidenced 
by the rising numbers of affluent Mongolians (and the less affluent, who often go into debt) who 
seek  medical  care  abroad.  Many  reasons  underlie  poor  health  care  quality  in  Mongolia, 
including  limited  resources  for  staff,  underdeveloped  quality  improvement  systems,  poor 
monitoring  systems,  lack  of  incentives  to  provide  better  quality  care,  weak  organizational 
processes, and under trained staff and managers. A range of financial and nonfinancial options 
are  available  for  long-term  systematic  improvement.  These  include  financing  systems  and 
incentives to improve quality and outcomes, strengthening quality improvement mechanisms in 
hospitals, better use of guidelines, strengthening monitoring, training, and more effective quality 
monitoring and use of data and indicators for evidence-based policy making. Implementation of 
these  kinds  of  activities—many  of  which  were  proposed  under  HSDP  and  SHSDP—has  been 
sporadic to date. 
 
14.

population,  compared  with  5.78  per  100,000  for  Commonwealth  of  Independent  States 
countries),4 and  the  hospital  sector  consumes  the  bulk  of  the  Government’s  health  spending. 
Public hospitals and facilities in the capital city, with a population of around 900,000, include 16 
clinical and tertiary hospitals and centers and some 46 hospitals of various types. There is also 
a  large  and  growing  private  health  sector  of  hospitals,  clinics,  laboratories,  and  pharmacies 
concentrated in Ulaanbaatar. There has been only limited consolidation of facilities over the past 
few  years.  In  addition  to  surplus  capacity  and  staff,  other  shortcomings  include  inappropriate 
hospital admissions and clinical practices, an ineffective referral system, ineffective distribution

Poorly  Developed  Health  Care  Financing  and  Health  Insurance.  Mongolian  public 
health  care  expenditure  is  relatively  low,  at  around  5%  of  GDP,  but  increasing  funding  and 
investment  is  only  a  partial  answer.  Mongolian  health  financing  is  inefficient  in  many  ways. 
Financial arrangements with hospitals are fragmented, funded from the government budget and 
health  insurance;  financing  is  not  linked  to  performance  or  efficiency;  incentives  are  perverse, 
encouraging  inappropriate  admissions  and  unnecessary  time  in  the  hospital;  costing  data  is 
lacking;  financial  allocations  favor  larger  hospitals  over  smaller  rural  facilities;  and  there  is 
disproportionate  spending  overall  on  hospitals  rather  than  on  public  health  or  preventive 
services.  
 
17. 
The  Government  is  currently  improving  health  financing  strategies,  and  a  number  of 
initiatives are being reviewed with technical assistance support from ADB.5 These include output 
based  budgeting,  single  purchaser  model,  case  mix  and  per  capita  funding,  and  global 
budgeting and performance based payment and incentives. Despite relatively low expenditures 
on health, the Mongolian health system has the potential to perform much more effectively, with 
improvements to operating efficiency linked to better financing strategies and targeted funding 
based on improving performance. 
 
18.  Weak  Human  Resources  Development  (HRD).  The  health  sector  HR  system  is 
marked  by  oversupply  of  doctors,  low  ratios  of  nurses  to  doctors,  misdistribution  of  key 
personnel  with  critical  shortages  in  rural  and  remote  areas,  and  poor  career  development 
opportunities. This situation is likely to further reduce quality and performance in the sector. HR 
planning and policy capacity is weak, and there is little linkage of training and curricula to future 
professional requirements.

Rationale  for  the  Project.  HSDP and SHSDP helped implement initial sector reforms, 
develop PHC, and improve infrastructure and service delivery. Nevertheless, further assistance 
is needed to consolidate and continue implementation of health reform in line with HSMP. There 
is wide disparity in access to health services, quality of services, and health outcomes between 
urban and rural areas in Mongolia. There is a need for significant upgrading of infrastructure to 
improve  rural  health  services,  particularly  in  aimags  which  have  so  far  received  little  or  no 
investment. There is also a need to build on the policy reforms advanced under previous health 
sector  development  initiatives:  expanding  and  improving  PHC,  improving  financial  expenditure 
for  increased  system  efficiency,  expanding  health  insurance  coverage,  and  improving  HR 
capacity. Policy reform in these areas requires continual support and attention for a number of 
reasons. First, the entrenched structure and processes of health systems like that of Mongolia, 
which were strongly influenced by the Semashko model,6 need comprehensive reengineering to 
make  them  efficient  and  effective  in  addressing  health  needs  generally  and  needs  of 
disadvantaged7 groups and the poor in particular. Second, rapid and high turnover of staff in key 
roles and positions makes continuity difficult. Third, effective change needs targeted incentives, 
and these are not always available or readily applicable. Finally, change invariably encounters 
resistance  from  affected  or  threatened  parties,  which  impedes  the  progress  of  reforms.

be discriminated against based on ethnic origin and guarantees equal access to education and 
health  for  ethnic  minorities.  The  cultural  distinction,  health,  and  socioeconomic  status  of  this 
group,  as  revealed  through  data  collection  during  project  preparation,  are  similar  to  those  of 
other Mongolians. Given the equal levels of social indicators between the Khalkh majority and 
ethnic  minorities,  no  indigenous  people’s  development  plan  or  special  actions  in  favor  of  any 
particular group are needed.  
 
D. 
  
67. 
The Project has a strong focus on improving the institutional, operational, and financial 
efficiency  of  the  Mongolian  health  system.  Economic  internal  rates  of  return  (EIRR)  were 
calculated  for  the  Project,  and  main  benefits  quantified  were  resource  cost  savings  and 
productivity gains.  
 
Resource cost savings consist of reducing out-of-pocket expenses for health care as a 
68. 
result of reforms in health financing. Productivity gains are the results of less time lost to illness 
that would have otherwise been utilized in some  economic activity. Productivity gains will also 
be  realized  through  less  time  being  spent  for  the  care  of  sick  family  members.  Direct  and 
indirect health benefits are potentially significant due to fewer days lost at work and school and 
general  improvement  in  health  status  and  life.  The  analysis  does  not  attempt  to  quantify  all 
economic  gains  and  provides  only  conservative  estimates  based  on  quantifiable  benefit 
streams.  Overall  investments  under  the  Project  are  expected,  however,  to  yield  significant 
economic, social, and institutional benefits. The Project yields a 22.8% EIRR and a net present 
value  of  MNT11.3  billion.  The  net  present  value  calculation  discounts  the  cost  and  benefit 
streams  at  12%  in  real  terms.  The  economic  and  financial  analyses  are  summarized  in 
Appendix 14 and set out in detail in Supplementary Appendix K. 
 
69. 
Financial  goals  of  the  Project  include  improving  allocative  efficiency  in  health  care 
expenditure  (shifting  funding  away  from  hospitals  to  PHC)  and  improving  internal  operating 
efficiency  and  financial  management  in  service  delivery,  thus  reducing  health  care  costs  for 
individuals  and  the  community  overall.  Incremental  recurrent  costs  of  the  Project  are 
manageable and arise largely from  increased operation and maintenance (O&M)  costs for the 
facilities constructed and upgraded under the Project. 
  
The  financial  analysis  evaluates  the  impact  of  the  Project  on  the  Government  budget. 
70.

for around 5 years. The Government’s annual share in Project costs will average approximately

budget of about $87.2 million. The recurrent costs to be borne by the Government during project 
implementation  are  estimated  to  be  about  $107,000  equivalent  (MNT128  million)  per  year.

THE MONGOLIA HEALTH SECTOR 

Overview 

 
A. 
 
1. 
Organizational  Structure.  From the 1920s to the 1990s, Mongolia had centralized the 
hierarchical  health  system.  Health  services  were  fully  financed  and  delivered  by  the 
Government, with a strong orientation towards curative services that relied greatly on hospital-
based physicians and strong central control. Dismantling this legacy has proved challenging in 
reforming the health care system.   
 
Mongolia’s  health  care  system  is  one  statutory  system  organized  by  administrative 
2. 
divisions. In addition to the capital city of Ulaanbaatar, there are 21 aimags (provinces), each of 
which  is  split  into  smaller  soums  (districts).  Soums  are  further  divided  into  3–4  smaller  bags 
(village units), depending on their population sizes. Decentralization of the health care system 
started in the mid-1990s in response to reduced central government funding for health.  
 
3. 
Provision  of  Services.  In  urban  areas,  primary  health  care  (PHC)  services  are 
delivered  by  family  group  practices  (FGPs),  which  were  initiated  under  the  Health  Sector 
Development  Program  (HSDP)  that  was  financed  by  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  In  rural 
areas,  PHCs  are  provided  by  soum  health  centers  (SHCs)  and  bag  feldshers  (community 
nurses),  who  are  medically  trained  primary  health  care  workers  at  the  smallest  administrative 
unit. Feldshers report to SHCs through regular meetings and visits and, in case of emergencies, 
refer clients to SHCs or inter-SHCs.  
 
4. 
Specialized  care  is  delivered  by  aimag  general  hospitals  (AGH)  and  urban  district 
hospitals,  which  cover  all  major  clinical  specialties  and  typically  have  capacities  of  200–300 
beds for delivering inpatient services. The next level of specialized care is provided through the 
state clinical hospitals and specialized health centers. These are located mainly in Ulaanbaatar, 
but also through the three regional treatment and diagnostic centers. Private sector provision of 
health care is mainly concentrated in Ulaanbaatar.  
 
5. 
Health  Indicators. Despite relatively low per capita income, Mongolia has quite strong 
health indicators. Since 1994, the trend in both under-five mortality and infant mortality has been 
consistently downwards. 
 
6. 
On  average,  Mongolia’s  infant  mortality  rate  is  significantly  less  than  that  of  other 
countries with similar gross domestic product (GDP) per capita. Under-five mortality is below the 
average of low-income countries and life expectancy at birth (65 in 2003) is higher than average 
for low-income countries. Tables A2.1, A2.2, and A2.3 outline key health indicators in Mongolia.

health insurance coverage, limited spending on PHC, informal payments (40% of patients now 
pay informally), and co-payments acting as a barrier to access by poor people.  
 
15. 
Quality considerations include low investment in technology and improved services (one 
reason  why  increasing  numbers  are  seeking  care  outside  of  the  country);  low  remuneration

determines  the  total  budget  to  be  allocated  to  the  health  sector.  Decisions  on  financial

sector;  plus  government  resolutions,  decrees,  and  national  health  programmes  related  to  the

policies  between  MOH  and  SSIGO,  there  is  little  or  no  coordination  of  service  purchasing 
policies between HIF and MOH.

has  been  estimated  that  7–10  hospitals  could  adequately  and  efficiently  serve  Ulaanbaatar’s 
population along with rural referrals. Savings from increasing the efficiency of the hospital sector 
could be used to fund investments in public health and PHC. Potential savings from optimization 
are estimated at MNT1 billion–MNT3 billion annually.3   
 
24. 
Growth of the Private Health Sector. In Mongolia, the opening of the market economy 
has  encouraged  significant  growth  in  the  private  health  sector.  Government  policy  enables 
private hospitals to compete with the public sector, and HIF funding allows private hospitals to 
receive  reimbursement  for  patients  under  public  subsidy.  In  principle,  private  health  care  can 
deliver quality and efficiency to the health sector, contribute to meeting health system goals, and 
complement public provision in an integrated fashion. However, in Mongolia the private sector is 
practically unregulated and has been growing very rapidly. There are no standards to determine 
quality  of  service  and  patient  safety;  no  definitions  or  criteria  for  defining  the  scope  of  clinical 
services;  and  no  standards  for  premises,  infrastructure,  or  equipment.  Many  private  hospitals 
consist of only 4–8 beds and have no insurance.  
 
25. 
A functioning institutional and regulatory environment is needed in Mongolia to facilitate 
the appropriate involvement of the private sector in the planned and strategic delivery of health 
services. Mongolia needs policies for private sector development, accreditation of hospitals and 
facilities, and regulatory mechanisms to monitor performance and ensure safety and quality of 
care. 
 
26. 
Inadequate  Support  for  PHC.  Despite emphasizing the importance of PHC in various 
laws, regulations, and policies, support for public health and for the most significant element of 
PHC  development  in  Mongolia,  the  FGP  system,  has  been  inconsistent.  Since  the  initial 
establishment  of  FGPs  in  1999–2001,  the  situation  for  family  doctors  has  deteriorated,  with 
severely constrained funding resulting in low and decreasing doctor and nurse incomes, as well 
as a lack of investment in infrastructure, premises, and equipment. Moreover, there are unclear 
legal and regulatory processes that disadvantage doctors’ status and social standing.  
 
27. 
Lack of Governance, Monitoring, and Regulation. A principal reason for many of the 
health  system  problems  is  weakness  in  governance  and  regulation.  Government  and  its 
agencies have paid insufficient attention to monitoring, direction and guidance, as evidenced by 
the uncontrolled growth of the private sector; lack of a legal basis for FGPs; lack of application 
of routine administrative, financial and clinical data; and, until the recent initiation of  the Master 
Plan process, lack of overall strategic direction. 
 
C. 
 
In  the  transition  from  a  Soviet-based  health  system  towards  a  mixed  public-private 
28. 
model  focusing  on  PHC  with  coordinated  secondary  and  tertiary  services,  Mongolia  has  had 
only uneven success to date. Overall, health outcomes and indicators are improving, but in the 
health system generally there are significant problems of poor quality of care, inefficiency, and 
inadequate  implementation  of  reform  and  improvement  strategies.  The  HSMP,  with  its  sector-
wide approach, provides a sound basis to make progress on these and other issues.

economic  development.  Improved  health  care  expands  economic  opportunities  for  people,  including  the  poor  and 
disadvantaged,  by  building  human  capital,  as  expressed  in  good  health,  well-being  and  capacity  for  work.  Healthy 
people  actively  engage  in  economic  activities,  thus  increasing  productivity.  Reliable  health  services  reduce  such 
lifecycle risks to the individual as illness, injury, disability, and early death, thereby also preventing impoverishment.  
 
Improving  health  services  and  the  health  status  of  the  population  will  reduce  government  as  well  as  household 
expenditure. Mongolia’s extensive system of social safety nets costs about 7% of gross domestic product per year, of 
which  40%  is  devoted  to  social  assistance  for  the  poor  and  the  disadvantaged.  Maintaining  and  improving  social 
service delivery prevents new incidences of poverty that are caused by poor health and educational deprivation.   
 
In Mongolia, access and quality of social services is both a push and a pull factor in current migration. Rural people 
with few adequate skills and experience living in settled areas face problems in coping with urban life. Moreover, they 
have limited support networks and few income earning opportunities. Therefore, the risk of falling into poverty is high. 
Improving health services in rural and peri-urban areas will significantly slow migration and reduce poverty.  
 
The Project will contribute to achieving Mongolia’s Millennium Development Goals, particularly goals 4, 5, and 6 and 
targets 5, 6, 7, and 8 to (i) reduce by two thirds the under-five mortality rate, (ii) reduce by three quarters the maternal 
mortality  rate,  (iii)  halt  by  2015  and  begin  to  reverse  the  spread  of  HIV/AIDS,  and  (iv)  halt  by  2015  and  begin  to 
reverse the incidence of malaria and other major diseases. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis  
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
According to the HIE/LSM 2002/03 survey,1 around 900,000, or 36%, of Mongolians live in poverty.2 Poverty is higher 
in  rural  areas  than  in  urban  areas  (43%  versus  30%).  The  so-called  poverty  gap  stands  at  11%  and  estimates  the 
average shortfall in consumption relative to the poverty line. This figure implies that the per person cost of eliminating 
poverty is 11% of the poverty line. 
 
In contrast to the head count or to the poverty gap, the severity of poverty is 4.7%. Both, the poverty gap and severity 
are higher in rural than in urban areas. At the regional level, the West is the poorest region. The poverty incidence in 
the  West  represents  more  than  half  of  the  population.  This  figure  is  almost  two  fifths  in  the  Highland  region  and 
around one third in both the Central and East regions.  
 
Ulaanbaatar displays the country’s lowest level of poverty, and slightly more than one quarter of its residents are poor. 
Following the capital city by poverty measures are the aimag (provincial) centers and then rural areas. 
 
Health challenges in Mongolia include maternal mortality rates, a high incidence of tuberculosis, and  poor quality  of 
public  health  care  services.  Over  the  last  10  years,  Mongolia  has  achieved  certain  progress  in  reducing  infant 
mortality  and  mortality  of  children  under  5  years  of  age.  A  2003  survey  established  that  the  causes  of  maternal 
mortality are associated with decreasing level and quality of medical services (36%), delay in emergency medical aid 
(28%), and living far from medical institutions. 
 
Child  and  maternal  mortality  are  directly  linked  to  poverty.  Infants  and  undernourished  pregnant  women  from  poor 
families are much more likely to die or suffer complications than are well-nourished mothers and their offspring.3 The 
infant mortality rate per 1,000 live births has fallen from 31.23 in 2000 to 20.8 in 2005. The under-5 child mortality rate 
has also decreased from 42.4 to 26.1. The rural-urban  gap  remains substantial, however, as those figures are 18.1 
and 21.7, respectively, in urban areas but 22.5 and 28.9 in rural areas. The  two most frequent and persistent causes

having increased by more than 2.5 times since 1991. There are 30 cases of individuals diagnosed HIV positive and 
four cases of death from AIDS. 
 
Poor people tend to be more affected by infectious diseases. Mongolia is one of seven Asia-Pacific countries cited by 
World  Health  Organization  as  having  high  incidence  of  tuberculosis.  Most  people  with  tuberculosis  are  unemployed 
and either poor or extremely  poor. There are also male health concerns, such as a comparatively  high incidence of 
stroke and heart disease from age 40 onwards. This appears to be linked to poor diet, high levels of tobacco use, and 
alcohol  abuse.  According  to  HIE/LSM  2002/03  survey,  health  spending  averages  5%  of  household  consumption  for 
the population as a  whole. For poor households, that figure averages 4.5% and for non-poor households it is 5.4%. 
Because of their inability to pay for the services in cash, medical services consumption of the poor is quite low. The 
incidences  of  major  diseases  causing  morbidity  and  mortality  are  increasing  among  rural  populations.  This 
demonstrates that the quality and availability of medical services in rural areas is poor and inadequate.  
 
The Project will be implemented in five rural aimags (Arkhangai, Dundgovi, Govi-Altai, Sukhbaatar, and Tuv) and two 
duuregs of Ulaanbaatar (Chingeltei and Songinokhairkhan) benefiting client population or more than 700,000. About 
40.4% of the population in the project aimags is poor, compared to the national average of 36%. Overall, the Project 
aims to improve and extend primary health care (PHC) services to benefit the Mongolian population, in particular, the 
rural poor, the urban underserved, women, children, and the elderly.

between institutions and the community. The Project aims to shift people’s attitudes from curative to preventive care,

rural and urban family group practices; (ii) raise awareness among the population, health workers, and policymakers 
on  the  extent  and  effects  of  catastrophic  payments;  and  (iii)  develop  and  implement  in  project  areas  participatory 
mechanisms and processes for increased community involvement, including complaints procedures, public reporting,
